Studies from cities like San Francisco, New York, and Berlin have shown that rent control can significantly reduce displacement, particularly in high-cost urban areas where housing demand outstrips supply. Without rent control, landlords have unchecked power to raise rents arbitrarily, often exploiting market conditions to maximize profits. In the long term, the stability provided by rent control can also contribute to broader economic benefits. When people are not forced to move frequently due to rising rents, they are more likely to invest in education, start businesses, and contribute to local economies. This creates a more resilient and equitable housing system that supports long-term affordability for all.
